text:
Using CLUE’s Tools

It’s time to try out each of CLUE’s tools. You’ll decide which tools to use to solve a problem. Knowing how the tools work will help you present your mathematical answers in a way that makes sense to you, whether that’s in words or a graph or table. To use a tool, just click it. You can then move it to a particular section or above or below another tile. Or to position it precisely, drag it from the toolbar into your workspace, moving to where you want it (the drop zone is indicated by a blue vertical bar), then let go.

Text

When you click into a text tile or any tile in your workspace, a tray with icons for editing options appears below or above it. Hover your mouse over the items in the tray for more information (and keyboard shortcuts) about each.

The text tool is like many other editors, but some options may work slightly differently.

  1. To select text, click in the text tile, then drag over the text or use the arrow keys with the Shift key to select by character or Command-Shift for larger selections. (On a PC, use the Ctrl key instead of the Command key.) Note: Dragging where there is no text moves the whole text tile.
  2. To use an editing tool, select the text you want to format (e.g., bold, italicize, etc.), then click the tool, which will turn blue. Or click the tool first, and start typing formatted text.
  3. Be sure to click the tool again to deselect it when you’re done.

Drag this tile into the Initial Challenge section in your workspace, and format the text below as described.

Bold

Italic

Underline

Subscript

Superscript

This is a

Numbered

List

This is a

Bulleted

List

Make a link (include full URL)

A few more things about text tiles:

When text is selected, you can use the usual keyboard shortcuts:

  • Cut: Command-X
  • Copy: Command-C
  • Paste: Command-V
  • Undo: Command-Z
  • Redo: Command-Shift-Z
  • Select all text in a tile: Command-A

Table

Use a table to relate two or more quantities. Tables can hold numbers or text. You can edit the table title or column labels by double-clicking. You can move from cell to cell with the tab key. Below are some example tables. Drag each one into the Initial Challenge section and make the suggested edits.

Explore the table functions. See if you can add another column and label it Height (ft.), then fill the column with heights. You can make up the numbers (or research them, if you want). Also, add another dinosaur or two and fill out the columns with numbers.

Tables can help you see patterns. Here is a table that shows the number of ways points (not on a line) can be connected with straight lines. Put this in the Initial Challenge workspace and add a row or two. Can you continue the pattern for 6 and 7 points or more? Add a text tile to describe how you solved it.
Tables have more features that we’ll explore later in this activity.

Two Types of Graph

CLUE's two graph types work in a similar way, but have different uses:

  • Coordinate Grid - for shapes and geometry, the grid is always square like graph paper.
  • Graph - for number relationships and graphing equations.

Coordinate Grid

Play with shapes. Drag the Coordinate Grid below into the Initial Challenge. Try to:

  • Duplicate the shapes and make a pattern of tiles by moving them and rotating them.
  • Make new polygons.
  • Select different part of the shapes and discover how the label tool works. It can do more than label!
  • Control your view of the shapes with the zoom, and Fit all options.
  • Slip an image under the grid using Upload Image.
  • A hidden feature: Use the arrow keys to nudge any selected object (points, lines, shapes) by 0.1 unit to get it exactly where you want it.

Graph

The Graph tool allows you to present number relationships in many different ways. You can change the axes of the graph independently so the lines of the grid are not always square.

Try different ways to represent number relationships on the Graph.

Adding points by hand. Drag a new Graph tile into into the Initial Challenge workspace, and click Add points by hand on the Graph tool tray. As you click on the graph, the points connect to show that you are forming a mathematical relationship between the points. Remove points by clicking Select, then highlight individual points and delete them. The lines will reconnect. Select multiple points with shift-click.

Plot data from a table. Drag another Graph into your workspace, and select Add Data. The tables that you brought into your workspace are listed in a dialog box. (If you skipped that, drag those tables in now.) In the dialog box, select one of the data tables and the graph will plot it for you!
You can try out the remaining features and some tricks with the Coordinate Grid and Graph tool later in this activity.

Sketch

This simple draw tool can help you explain your answers when nothing else will. Drag a new Sketch tool into the Initial Challenge workspace, and try it out.

Every item that you add to a sketch gets listed in the Show/sort panel. Clicking on an item in the show/short list selects it in the sketch. You can select multiple items with a shift-click. You can show or hide items clicking on the eye icon or drag an item in the list using the waffle to change its level.

Equation

The Equation tool is for typing mathematical expressions. Mostly, you will use the keyboard to enter an expression:

  • Use "+", "-", and "*" to add, subtract and multiply.
  • Click the divide symbol in the tool tray to divide.
  • To write a fraction type the numerator, then "/", and then the denominator.
  • For a mixed fraction, click the mixed fraction icon in the tool tray.
  • Use the tab key, arrow keys, or the mouse to move between the different parts of the expression.
  • You can change the label at the left to describe your mathematical expression.

Drag the two Equation tools below into the Initial Challenge and try editing them. Drag in a fresh Equation tool from the tool bar and edit that.

Number Line

  1. The Number Line tool has many uses. For instance, it can help understand how mathematical operations work, particularly problems involving negative numbers. The Number Line below shows the answer to 2 - 5 where the "-" sign indicates counting 5 units to the left. The endpoints can be changed.

Drag a Number Line into the Initial Challenge and try adding points. We will see other uses for this tool in the next section.

Image

Use the image tool to add a picture or snapshot to your work. For example, you might want to do some of your work with a pencil and paper. You can take a picture of it with the computer’s camera or a cell phone camera and upload it to your workspace. Then, all your work is together and your teacher can easily see it.

tiles.title: Snapshot of physical work loaded in CLUE

text:
You can upload an image three ways: (1) Drag an image (JPG, PNG) from your computer directly into your workspace, (2) Drag and drop an image into a new image tool, or (3) Use the Upload Image option below the image tool to upload the file.

Of course, you can always drag an image from a problem into your workspace.

A Fun Challenge

To learn more about the difference between the Coordinate Grid and the Graph, try this:

  1. Drag the table labeled Dog into your workspace.
  2. Drag both a new Coordinate Grid and a new Graph into your workspace.
  3. Add the Dog table data to both graphs types.
  4. If you wish, connect the points of the Dog data in the Coordinate Grid using the Polygon tool to outline the dog.
  5. Answer the questions in the text tile below.

What can you do with the dog in both graphs?

Try selecting different parts of the dog in each graph--points, lines, and the whole animal. Then test the different graph types. Record what you find out. Try answering these questions:

  1. What can you move with the mouse, and what won't move?
  2. Can you duplicate the figure (make a copy)?
  3. If you can make a copy, try doing things with the copy.
  4. Can you move it? Rotate it? Stretch it?
  5. Can you measure a length of one segment?

See if you can unlink the graph. What happens?
